story.focusNode: عبد الْوَاحِد بن مُحَمَّد بن عَليّ بن أَحْمد الشِّيرَازِيّ أبي الفرج
story.storyHtml:
Zayn al-Din Ibn Naja was the grandson of Ahmad al-Shirazi Abi al-Faraj who was considered one of the greatest Hanbali scholars of his age and who moved from Baghdad to Palestine then Damascus where he taught. He played a seminal role in the spread of the Hanbali school in Syria. Ibn Rajab considered him to be the greatest Hanbali scholar in Syria. Ibn Asakir notes that al-Shirazi spread the Hanbali madhhab in Jerusalem and Damascus.

Sharaf al-Islam Abd al-Wahab was the son of Abu Faraj and the uncle of Ibn Naja.

شرف الإسلام عبد الوهاب بن أبي الفرج الحنبلي

story.storyHtml:
Sharaf al-Islam was the teacher of Uthman b. Marzuq who studied under him in Damascus. Uthman b. Marzuq became a disciple of Abd al-Qadir al-Jilani. It is said (reported in ibn Rajab) that he accompanied Jilani on the pilgrimage to Mecca where he became his disciple and read hadith with him. It is also said that Abi Madyan al-Ansari was present with the two men. According to Vincent Cornell, Abu Madyan never travelled East to perform the pilgrimage, nor is there any mention in the tabaqat works relating to al-Jilani. One also takes into account how frequently accounts of saintly figures in medieval Islam have been subjected to embellishments and apocryphal ascriptions.

And yet al-Jilani’s son, Abdel-Raziq does say, ‘when my father, May Allah have Mercy upon him, went on pilgrimage in the year in which I was with him during it, he met with two Shaykhs, Ibn Marzuq and Abu Madyan. The two wore cloaks from him (ie they became disciples).’ Sa'd b. Uthman the son of Uthman b. Marzuq left Cairo for Baghdad where he remained for the rest of his life. Buried in the ribat of al-Jilani. Funeral prayers were held for him in the madrasa of Abd al-Qadir (Al-Qadisi). However, when it came for him to be buried, the mother of the Caliph sent her servants to take the body and had it interred in a tomb near her tomb place.

story.storyHtml: Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Qudama studied underAbu Faraj. It was Abu Faraj who introduced the Hanabli school to Qudamas. The massacre at al-Aqsa, as well as other massacres, sparked waves of flight of residents from Jerusalem, amongst whom were many scholars and jurists. In the village of Jama‘il, 16 kilometres south west of Nablus, the Hanbali Ibn Qudama rallied the farmers and peasants to sabotage and boycott the Crusaders. His fiery sermons attracted many who flocked to Jama‘il on Fridays where they also attended lessons in Quran recitation and listened to hadith. Anger was reaching boiling point as stretches of their agricultural lands was given to the new settlers. News of the sermons of Ibn Qudama, reached the Franks, ‘this faqih prevented the peasants from working the land and they gathered around him. So, they, and in particular Balian of ‘Ibilin (known as Balian ibn Barisan), the Crusader ruler of Nablus spoke about having him killed.’ When Ahmed heard of this, he escaped to Damascus. In 1156 Ahmad was the first of the Qudama family to arrive in Damascus, a city with close trading and scholarly links to Nablus. As soon as Ahmed arrived, he sent for his son, Muwaffaq al-Din Ibn Qudama who brought the rest of the family. The Qudama family inspired others to relocate to Damascus. These immigrants became known as Maqdisis (Jerusalemites). However, tensions between Ahmad and the local Hanbalis arose. News of the quarrel reached Nur al-Din Zengi who was sitting with his chief judge Abdullah Ibn Abi 'Asrun, a follower of the Shafi’i madhhab. When Nur al-Din asked him for his advice, he commended the Qudama immigrants, remarking that many of them knew the Qur’an by heart.

story.stageLabel: Jilani and his followers in Baghdad
story.storyHtml:
Abdullah Ibn Abi 'Asrun travelled to Baghdad where he studied under Abd al-Qadir al-Jilani

Muwaffaq al-Din Ibn Qudama was the cousin of Abd al-Ghani al-Maqdisi. The two travelled to Baghdad where they met and became disciples of al-Jilani.

Abu Majd 'Aisa Muwaffaq al-Din Ibn Qudama was the son of Muwaffaq al-Din Ibn Qudama. He studied under Fatima bt. al-Hasan Sa'd al-Khayr who was the wife of Zayn al-Din Ibn Naja and the daughter of Sa'd al-Khayr al-Ansari under whom Ibn Naja studied.

Ibn Naja travelled to Baghdad where he studied under several teachers and became a student and disciple of Abd al-Qadir al-Jilani.

It was al-Jilani who instructed Ibn Naja to travel to Fatimid Egypt. But first he was told to head to Damascus with a message for Nur al-Din Zengi.

story.focusNode: زين الدين أبو الحسن علي بن إبراهيم بن نجا
story.storyHtml: Abd al-Qadir al-Jilani told Zayn al-Din Ibn Naja, 'You will reach Damascus and you will find there an army ready to invade Egypt. Say: you will not conquer it on this occasion. Is it not better for you to turn back so that you conquer it on another?' In Damascus Ibn Naja related the message and was instructed by Nur al-Din Zengi not to mention it to anyone.Ibn Naja also met Asad al-Din Shirkuh before heading to Egypt.

story.focusNode: زين الدين أبو الحسن علي بن إبراهيم بن نجا
story.storyHtml:
In Egypt, Zayn al-Din Ibn Naja met with Uthman b. Marzuq who taught at the Amr ibn al-As mosque and was a sufi shaykh with may followers. There is little doubt that this introduction had been facilitated by Abd al-Qadir al-Jilani for he had met with Uthman b. Marzuq during the pilgrimage where the Egyptian Shaykh had become a disciple. Uthman b. Marzuq asked Zayn al-Din Ibn Naja about his journey to Damascus and then told him, ‘Asad al-Din Shirkuh will come to this land [Egypt] and will go and will not gain anything, he will then return and depart and he will not gain this land. Then he will return and will take it and he will rule Egypt.’ Puzzled by those enigmatic utterances, he asked Uthman b. Marzuq, ‘Ya Sidi, from where do you get this knowledge?’ He replied, ‘My son, I do not know the Unseen but on occasion the Prophet comes to me and tells me.’

What is clear is that those in Baghdad and Damascus were preoccupied with affairs in Egypt and were plotting for the fall of the Fatimids and the restoration of Sunnism to the land of the Nile. Intriguingly both al-Jilani and Ibn Marzuq forewarned Ibn Naja that Shirkuh’s initial campaign would not succeed, and though this certainly can be read as examples of spiritual visions of the Shaykhs, it could also be read as astute political assessments that the Fatimid rule was not weak enough to fall.

story.stageLabel: Ibn Naja and the declining Fatimid dynasty
story.focusNode: زين الدين أبو الحسن علي بن إبراهيم بن نجا
story.storyHtml:
Intriguingly, while he was busy plotting with the Sunni elements in Egypt to undermine the Fatimids and passing messages back to Damascus, Zayn al-Din Ibn Naja was also making successful inroads among the Fatimid authorities. He managed to meet and gain the confidence of the Caliph 'Adid li-din Allah. He also met and won the favour of the vizier Tala'i b. Ruzzik who gave him 20,000 dinars and a house to live in.

While in Egypt Ibn Naja came to know al-Qadi al-Fadil as well as other important dignitaries. He also managed to infiltrate the circles of the poet 'Umara al-Yamani and reported back to Saladin that there was a plot against his life.

story.storyHtml: It was in Egypt that Zayn al-Din Ibn Naja came to know Saladin's family, including his father, Najm al-Din Ayyub, his brothers, Turan Shah and al-Malik al-Adil. He also knew Saladin's sons, al-Malik al-Aziz 'Imad al-Din, al-Malik al-Zahir Ghayath al-Din, and Abu al-Hassan Ali. He also knew Saladin’s nephew al-Malik al-Muzaffar.
